Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Functional Perspective on Adaptive Radiation: Explaining Differences in the Adaptive Radiations of Mainland and Island Anolis Lizards
Award.AbstractNarration:
Adaptive radiation, in which a clade diversifies from an ancestral form to produce descendants adapted to utilize a wide variety of ecological niches, has become a topic of great recent interest. The evolutionary radiation of Anolis lizards in the Caribbean has become a textbook case study of adaptive radiation, demonstrating that independent radiations can converge on very similar adaptive traits. This project expands this work to ask why in some cases evolutionary diversification yields very different results. On each island in the Greater Antilles, evolutionary radiation has occurred, producing species specialized to use different parts of the habitat (e.g., twigs, grass, canopy). Amazingly, evolution has occurred independently on each island, producing the same set of habitat specialists. Detailed analysis has indicated that strong relationships exist among species between anatomy and habitat use. Long-legged species occur on broad surfaces, for example, and more arboreal species have better developed toepads. Functional studies have explained these relationships by determining the relationship between morphology and functional performance capabilities, on one hand, and between performance abilities and habitat use and behavior, on the other. Anolis has also radiated widely in mainland Central and South America. Although less studied, these lizards have clearly evolved in different ways. Mainland anoles are as diverse among themselves as are island anoles, but the mainland species differ anatomically from the islands species. Most strikingly, the relationship between anatomy and habitat use differs fundamentally between mainland and island anoles.

The PIs will investigate whether differences in the anatomy~ecology relationship result because the relationship between functional capabilities and ecology differ or because the relationship between anatomy and functional capabilities differs (or both). In addition, the PIs will seek explanations for the variation in anatomy~performance relationships between island and mainland lizards, focusing on the physiological properties of muscles. Jointly the data collected to address these goals will enable the PIs to address the question of why mainland anoles have radiated in fundamentally different ways than island anoles. Undergraduate students, including women and individuals from underrepresented groups, a postdoctoral fellow and foreign collaborators will receive unique interdisciplinary training. The PIs will work with the Harvard Museum of Natural History to develop an exhibit on Anolis as a model system for understanding how evolution works.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Caribbean Anolislizards have become a model system for the study of adaptive radiation. Independent evolution of anoles on several Caribbean islands have resulted in “ecomorphs” that have similar behaviors, occupy similar ecological niches, and show striking similarities in morphological features, such as limb length. The goal of this project was to use this system to determine if physiological traits, such as maximum muscle force, muscle power, and twitch time have also evolved in parallel with morphological and performance traits. The aim was to use the diversity of both Caribbean species and species from mainland Central and South America to understand the relationship between morphology, physiology, and performance.

Results from the project show clear patterns of variation in muscle physiology that relate to performance. We compared the performance of jaw and limb muscles in six species of anoles. This comparison showed that these muscles differ in both their twitch times, a measure of how quickly the muscle can turn on and off, and the maximal shortening velocity of the muscles. Results show that limb muscles consistently have lower twitch times, indicating that they can activate and deactivate more rapidly than jaw muscles. Other experiments show that across species, variation in limb muscle twitch time correlates with top sprint speed. Species that sprint rapidly have low twitch times. This is consistent with our prediction that twitch time is an important determinant of variation in muscle performance. Differences in maximum shortening velocity were somewhat surprising, because they show that limb muscles that are fast by one measure (twitch times) are slow by another (shortening speed) when compared with jaw muscles. These results demonstrate that the link between muscle performance and movement performance may be quite specific to the particular movement task required. 

Another part of the project explored an explanation for the tendency of anoles to jump, rather than run, when moving quickly over level ground. We developed a model that suggests that jumping allows animals to recruit a greater muscle mass and improve performance for acceleration. The model predicts that as the incline of the ground increases, the advantages of jumping decrease. Data show that animals transition from jumping to running with increasing incline, as predicted. These results show how changes in gait characteristics can increase performance.

Results from this project will help inform out understanding of the evolution of musculoskeletal performance, as well as the link between muscle performance and locomotor performance. All vertebrate muscles share common features in their mechanic and energetic function, and movement is governed by physical laws. Thus, features of locomotor biomechanics and muscle function studied in lizards can be generalized to other species, including humans. 

The project provided interdisciplinary research training for one postdoctoral research associate, two graduates students, three undergraduate students, and a high school student.
